note.body:
Looking at the designs, I wonder if unlabeled keys like Delete and Return are intentional, or just an incomplete sketch. To me they feel like a bug

And ftr, my keyboard doesn't say "Alt Gr" anywhere. It does have Alt and Ctrl and Shift though

target_title: ZWNJ is shown as U+200C

note.body:
I think the Unicode proposal was delayed for lack of evidence of use (and if you think about it, it is a bit meta - it adds a bunch of codepoints that are "symbol for this other codepoint").

And even with Unicode coverage, you need a font that provides glyphs.

Drawing the images is the realistic path forward.

target_title: ZWNJ is shown as U+200C

note.body:
> For these, it would be good to have the name somewhere (tooltip?) or even a link to the relevant wikipedia article.

The gnome-shell OSK already has an SVG for ZWNJ. Maybe it makes sense to ask the designers to create SVGs for the things you listed here and stick them into a repo we can re-use? On the other hand, what are the chances we'll get UTF-8 codepoint for those symbols and a font supporting that?

target_title: ZWNJ is shown as U+200C

note.body: It does contain the important bits. Is this just a proposal or is it official unicode? And what fonts support this?

target_title: ZWNJ is shown as U+200C

note.body: In general, it would be better to draw a hexbox for things instead of the text `U+999` which escapes the layout. Using the functional name in the hexbox would be an improvement of that...

target_title: Add labels for some more keysyms

note.body:
Last I remember conversation around the [existing designs](https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Design/app-mockups/-/blob/master/keyboard-layout/keyboard-layout.png?ref_type=heads). The use of ⎇ for AltGr didn't get much traction, and it was preferred using "Alt Gr" as a string.

CC @aday, since the first commit doubles down a bit on single glyphs for special keys.

The changes LGTM.

target_title: ZWNJ is shown as U+200C

note.body:
Lets make a list keysyms and Unicode codepoints that pop up unexpectedly:

Keysyms founds:
- dead_belowcomma
- dead_greek
- dead_currency
- dead_belowmacron
- BackSpace
- Tab / ISO_Left_Tab
- Enter

For dead keys, I would recommend that the rendering should use ◌:

![Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_11-47-32](/uploads/014b746aa3433d0d97906b2acb539b60/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_11-47-32.png)

(this was produced with Noto Sans and combining marks, some misrenderings there,
but it mostly works)

Here is the mapping to dead keys:

![Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-05-41](/uploads/fc229cf888913fb4bd7044ca9729c805/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-05-41.png)

For other keysyms:

- BackSpace is ⌫, U+232B ERASE TO THE LEFT
- Tab is ⭾, U+2B7E HORIZONTAL TAB KEY
- Enter is ⏎, U+23CE RETURN SYMBOL

----

Unicode codepoints found
- U+200C, zero-width non-joiner (ZWNJ)
- U+200D, zero-width joiner (ZWJ)
- U+2060, word-joiner (WJ)
- U+202F, narrow non-break space (NNBSP)

For these, I would recommend taking inspiration from that Unicode proposal:

ZWNJ ![ZWNJ](/uploads/56496d8f7bea4513878a45b71e445b67/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-28.png)

ZWJ ![ZWJ](/uploads/f28de7cf09b305630fb5928b662af0b4/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-33.png) 

WJ ![WJ](/uploads/fe68becfe6a29ce74cf2dd58158eb964/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-38.png)

NNBSP ![NNBSP](/uploads/eee4e0f0e98b998e65038ea21b0e9a02/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-37-49.png)

Soft hyphen (SHY) ![SHY](/uploads/ae262929071d4fbac56c22a222cd8418/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-12.png)

Non-breaking hyphen ![Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-18](/uploads/9b140309924ceb910393d666f80a2671/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-18.png)

Zero-width space ![Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-04](/uploads/c560142be9fcf7225ac805c10e87dce2/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-04.png)

Left-to-right mark (LRM) ![Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-46](/uploads/cae26010708a3bb56ed24ec20899631e/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-46.png)

Right-to-left mark (RLM) ![Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-46](/uploads/31da3a8cad5b2e4f7c85805048ec0c2c/Screenshot_From_2024-12-12_12-38-46.png)

For these, it would be good to have the name somewhere (tooltip?) or even a link to the relevant wikipedia article.

target_title: ZWNJ is shown as U+200C

note.body:
Here is a Unicode proposal that shows some of the ISO symbols for default ignorables that we can use. It doesn't cover everything, but its a start:

https://unicode.org/wg2/docs/n4984-Unicode-Proposal-9995-V7.pdf

target_title: ZWNJ is shown as U+200C

note.body:
For such 'default ignorables', it might be good enough to show their 'functional name', ie the 3-4 letter all-caps string. Pango draws hexboxes for them. See

https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/pango/-/blob/main/pango/pango-impl-utils.h#L173

target_title: Some keys are displayed with a text "dead below …"

note.body:
I've seen these too. Examples in the French(Ergo-L) layout include: ISO_Level5_Latch, U+202F, dead_currency, dead_belowcomma

In the Russian(with Tatar letters) layout, I see U+2060.

target_title: No way to navigate with the keyboard

note.body:
AFAICS everything is usable with the keyboard. One just has to press the key that one wants more information about and switching between layers is done with the key(s) which do so.

Does navigation with the arrow keys have any benefit here?
